The latest available data shows London and the South East are now the only two regions to see wages above the national average. Overall median salaries for the UK increased from £18,848 in 2000 to £27,017 last year, roughly in line with inflation. The median wage in the North East was £17,430 in 2000. This was £1,418 less than the national average. During 2013 the average worker in the region took home £24,084 - a real-terms fall in wages since 2000 after inflation-and the pay gap has grown to £2,933. The north-south divide is growing, with workers in the North East now the worst paid in Britain. Wages in the rest of the country have fallen further behind London since 2000, a major study by the Office for National Statistics has shown.

The average wage throughout the civil service for grades 1 - 5 (which is 80% of all civil servants) is less that £20000 pa. Stuart Wilson, Motherwell. Andrew, Oxford says: To maintain any kind of decent lifestyle in the UK (especially the South East), one requires a salary of at least £60k.
